nexttext: The product $g_ig_j$ differs from a coset representative only by multiplication with an element $h_{i,j} \in H$, i.e. $g_ig_j = h_{i,j}g_k$. Hence it can be seen that the norm of the product is equal to the maximum of the values $||\sum_i \lambda_i(\mu_1) g_i\lambda_j(\mu_2)g_i^{-1}h_{i,j}||_r$. But we know that $||g_i\lambda_j(\mu_2)g_i^{-1}||_r = ||\lambda_j(\mu_2)||_r$. Moreover the norm is multiplicative and for any $h \in H$, $||h||_r = \prod ||h_i||_r^{x_i}$ but $||h_i||_r =||(h_i-1)+1||_r = \textnormal{max}\{1, ||h_i -1||_r\} = 1$ hence

nexttext: Now using Lemma \ref{52} we see that the syzygy ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n \otimes {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} S$ comes from the graded $0$ part of $M_n$ (as the image with respsect to the projection) after scalar extention (it is true for all the syzygys, but we only need the projective one). By Remark \ref{53} we know that scalar extention is faithfuly flat and now it follows that $Q(M_n) = {\textnormal{gr}^0} M_n$ (We abuse this notation) is graded-projective over ${\textnormal{gr}^0} R$. We have the natural projection $M_n \to {\textnormal{gr}^0} M_n = M_n/M_nI$ and since the latter is projective (it is projective as an ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R$-module since the action of ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R$ is via the projection ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R \to {\textnormal{gr}^0} R$), it induces a section $\gamma:{\textnormal{gr}^0} M_n = M_n/M_nI \to {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n$, so $\gamma \circ \pi = id$. We show that $M_n/M_nI \otimes_{{\textnormal{gr}^0} R} {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R \simeq {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n$. First we have a map $\nu: M_n/M_nI \otimes_{{\textnormal{gr}^0} R} {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R \to {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n \otimes_{{\textnormal{gr}^0} R} {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R \to {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M$. prevtext:
We know that $\gamma \circ \pi = id$, hence $Q(
u)$ is a graded isomorphism. Let us assume that $
u$ has a non-trivial cokernel. Then since $Q$ is right exact, $Q(coker
u) 
eq 0$ but we know for any non-zero graded module $N$ that $Q(N) 
eq 0$. Hence the above assumption is contradicting to the fact that $Q(
u)$ is an isomorphism. So at this point we have a surjective map $M_n/M_nI \otimes_{{	extnormal{gr}^0} R} {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R 	o {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n$. Let us now assume that $
u$ has a non-trivial kernel. $Q(M_n)$ is projective by the argument above, hence $M_n/M_nI \otimes_{{	extnormal{gr}^0} R} {\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R$ is also projective over ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} R$ and we have the following

\end{CD} \]

It means that ${\mathrm{gr}^{\cdot}} M_n$ is graded projective and for the filtration on ${	extnormal{Fil}^0(D_r(G,K))}$ is separated, exhaustive and complete, we can use Proposition I.$ 7.2.1$ in \cite{Hiu} to see that $M_n$ is filtered-projective. Hence we showed that there is a finite non-negative integer $n$ such that the $n$th syzygy in the filtered-free resolution is filtered-projective and it is a finite projective resolution of $J$ after applying the natural forgetful functor. Of course it is bounded above by $d$. Since $S$ is just the localization of $R$ by a central non-zero divisor, standard results show that the upper bound is in fact an equality. text: \[ F \supseteq K \supseteq pF \supseteq pK \supseteq p^2F \supseteq p^2K \supseteq \dots \]
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex60.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F\supseteq K\supseteq pF\supseteq pK\supseteq p^{2}F\supseteq p^{2}K\supseteq\dots" display="block"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⊇</mo><mi>K</mi><mo>⊇</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>⊇</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>⊇</mo><mrow><msup><mi>p</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>⊇</mo><mrow><msup><mi>p</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>⊇</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi></mrow></math>

nexttext: Now this is also an exact sequence of $R$-modules with the $R$-action induced by the surjection $\pi:R \to R/Rp$ (in this case the category of $p$-torsion modules is a Serre-subcategory in $\textnormal{mod}-R$ and the objects in the category of $R/Rp$-modules are naturaly $p$-torsion $R$-modules and these objects form an exact subcategory in $p$-tors). By assumption $\textnormal{pd}_R(M) =n$ and since $\textnormal{pd}_R(F) =0$ (moreover it is a free $R/Rp$-module), using Theorem $\ref{pd}$ one sees that $\textnormal{pd}_R(F/Fp) =1$. Now by the properties of the projective dimension function (for details see $7.1.6.$ in \cite{CM}) we see that $\textnormal{pd}_R(K/Fp) \leq n-1$ (except the case when $\textnormal{pd}_R(M) = 1$ which we have already handled). But $K/Fp$ is also a strict $p$-torsion module since it is an $R/Rp$-module, hence the induction applies. So the order of $[K/Fp]$ is finite, say $k$. Now summing the exact sequence above finitely many times we get the following
prevtext: hence the following sequence of $R/Rp$-modules is exact
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex61.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{CD}0@>{}>{}>K/Fp@>{}>{}>F/Fp@>{}>{}>M@>{}>{}>0\end{CD}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mi>M</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

By assumption $\textnormal{pd}_R(M) =n$ and since $\textnormal{pd}_R(F) =0$ (moreover it is a free $R/Rp$-module), using Theorem $\ref{pd}$ one sees that $\textnormal{pd}_R(F/Fp) =1$. Now by the properties of the projective dimension function (for details see $7.1.6.$ in \cite{CM}) we see that $\textnormal{pd}_R(K/Fp) \leq n-1$ (except the case when $\textnormal{pd}_R(M) = 1$ which we have already handled). But $K/Fp$ is also a strict $p$-torsion module since it is an $R/Rp$-module, hence the induction applies. So the order of $[K/Fp]$ is finite, say $k$. Now summing the exact sequence above finitely many times we get the following

prevtext: Define $R : = \mathcal{O}_K[[G]]$ again. By Devissage Theorem, we can identify the first group with $G_0(R/Rp)$ since for any finitely generated $p$-torsion module $M$, there exist a positive integer $n$, such that $Mp^n = 0$ therefore there is a filtration  $M \supset Mp \supset Mp^2 \supset \dots \supset Mp^{n-1} \supset 0$ and all the quotients are $R/Rp$-modules. So the class $[M]$ is equal to the class $\sum[Mp^{i-1}/Mp^{i}]$. All the modules $Mp^{i-1}/Mp^{i}$ are finitely generated strict $p$-torsion modules. Hence by Lemma \ref{61} the classes of these modules in $G_0(\textnormal{mod}-R)$ have finite order. Since all the Grothendieck groups are Abelian, we have the following equality:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex64.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="([M])^{k}=k[M]=\sum k[Mp^{i-1}/Mp^{i}]=\sum([Mp^{i-1}/Mp^{i}])^{k}" display="block"><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>k</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>/</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mi>i</mi></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>/</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mi>i</mi></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>k</mi></msup></mrow></mrow></math>
